text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single miniature framed by red, green, and gold rule lines, centered on otherwise blank parchment with no accompanying text; wide margins surrounding the image, with a small heraldic shield in the upper right corner

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold reserved for halos and framing lines, emphasizing sanctity; red used for angel’s wing feathers and border accents; green employed in underdress folds and tree foliage; layered washes of azurite and verdigris create depth in drapery; white highlights applied over pigments for volume; overall minimal oxidation indicates well-preserved pigments

features: Tall angel figure at center, vertical emphasis
Kneeling haloed saint to left, creating diagonal interaction
Small mound of earth with three budding trees to right balancing composition
Heraldic shield in upper right corner offsetting figural group

decorative_elements: Triple rule border in red, green, and gold
Heraldic cartouche with cityscape and red shield
Thin gold fillet framing the scene

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill-pen outlines in brown iron-gall ink, varying line weight for drapery folds
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle watercolor washes for tonal modulation in garments and flesh, white lead highlights on robes
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Absence of true linear perspective, depth suggested by overlapping figures and receding ground line, hierarchical scaling with angel slightly larger

content_theme.scene_description: This single miniature depicts two figures on a low earthen mound set against a plain background. On the right stands an angel, draped in a long, pale blue tunic belted at the waist, with large wings tinted red and grey, and a simple circular halo in burnished gold. The angel’s right hand clasps the saint’s raised left hand while the left arm gestures in blessing. To the left, a kneeling female saint, crowned with a gold halo, is attired in a crimson outer robe lined in green over a violet inner tunic; her bare feet rest on the same mound. Her posture is slightly inclined forward, arms extended as if seeking guidance. Three small budding trees to the right, each with a stubby trunk and spherical cluster of green leaves, indicate a garden setting. In the upper right corner, a heraldic shield bearing a red field and white roundel beneath a small cityscape interrupts the border. The composition emphasizes the spiritual encounter through the diagonal connection of hands and the contrast of vertical and kneeling forms.

religious: Standing angel with halo and wings

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, smoothly prepared with visible faint ruling on flesh side, regular quaternion gatherings indicated by quire marks
technical_features.preservation_condition: Excellent overall preservation; pigments vivid with minimal flaking in red areas, slight cockling at lower edge, no modern overpainting observed
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso underlay beneath gold leaf in halos
Underdrawing visible under infrared, especially in drapery folds
Gold punchwork pattern in border corners

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This delicate miniature, likely produced in a mid-14th-century court workshop, reflects the heightened emphasis on personal contemplation of Christ’s resurrection typical of the period. The precise quill-pen outlines and layered pigments—burnished gold, azurite blue, and vermilion—exemplify technical mastery consistent with high-end devotional manuscripts, such as Books of Hours commissioned by nobility. The iconography, showing a kneeling female saint clasping an angel’s hand, aligns with the Noli me tangere motif. Here, the angelic figure, rather than a cruciform Christ, underscores a devotional interpretation focused on angelic mediation. The inclusion of a heraldic shield suggests a named patron, integrating personalized commemoration within the sacred image. Stylistically, the work combines Gothic linear grace with subtle volumetric shading, indicating collaboration between draughtsman and colorist. The absence of true perspective but the use of overlapping figures and a receding ground line points to transitional spatial conventions. Comparatively, the miniature shares compositional parallels with Parisian illuminations yet displays coloristic affinities to the English Channel style, suggesting cross-Channel artistic exchange. Overall, this leaf offers a rich synthesis of devotional intent, heraldic personalization, and sophisticated material execution within the courtly manuscript tradition.
